This game needs to be dethroned. I used to go to a competitive Scrabble Club, and it was a lot of fun if you play this game by tournament standards! But for a casual board game night with friends, this game is not fun! It's cruel, inaccessible, there are tons of arguments over what constitutes as a valid word (scrabble dictionary, valid "2 letter" words, etc.) and there are way better word games out there like Bananagrams, Letter Jam, Kittos, etc! There is also a huge luck element to this game over which tiles you draw from the bag, and you have to be a seasoned player to count tiles and understand which tiles are worth keeping. Plus, you can easily win the game if you go for the double and triple word scores, despite having good words. It rewards location of letters rather than word creativity. It is sadly even worse online, I think playing by tournament rules in person is the way to play, and even then the game becomes more of a skill like chess rather then a nice family game it's advertised and known for.

UPDATE: I've started watching Dweebovision on Youtube, he's a competitive Scrabble player, and he's a total Chad, and has reignited my love for competitive Scrabble. If you ever find this comment, check him out, he's hilarious and you will not regret it xD

As someone remarked pointedly, a game about verbal mastery, where a formidable portion of points is gained by laying down banal monosyllables. My native language is Finnish, in which words are relatively long, certain consonants (e.g. q, f, g, b, c) are very rare, and the consonant-vowel ratio is low, three facts that the Finnish version of the game does not take into consideration sufficiently enough. The result is that you are left wandering around with too little amount of vowels to come up with any kind of creative outcome. For me this game is not a monster, it is an undead – it is a pale creep that sucks life out of you.

Párok számára ideális játéknak érzem abból a szempontból, hogy mind a férfi-, mind a női agy számára hasonló szintű kihívást jelent, és mindenki hasonlóan próbál boldogulni játék közben. Kifejezetten könnyen tanulható, de jó, ha van a közelben szótár, mert konfrontációra adhat okot, hogy valamely szót elfogadjuk-e, vagy sem. (Én szerencsére a párommal egész hasonlóan éreztem, hogy mely szavakat fogadhassuk még el, és melyeket már ne, csak az "oké" szóról vélekedünk eltérően.)
A játék során könnyen előfordul az, hogy hosszasan elgondolkozik az ember amikor rákerül a sor, ez hátrány. Hátrány az is, hogy a végjátékban frusztráló, hogy semmilyen értelmes szót nem tudunk már kirakni, hiába nézzük akárhogy a táblát és a betűinket (bár ez nem mindig van így, van, hogy semmi gond a végjátékkal).
előfordul, hogy valamelyik játékos folyamatosan használhatatlan betűket húz, míg egy másik játékos meg csupa jót - ez elveheti a kedvet a játéktól.
Összességében üde színfolt a matematika-alapú társasjátékok mellett, örülök neki és szívesen játszom vele. És kíváncsi vagyok merre alakul majd a véleményem a további játékok során.

Update: Mostanra egyáltalán nem vonz ez a játék, nem szívesen ülnék le vele játszani. Egyszerűen frusztrál, hogy semmi értelmes szót nem tudok kirakni szinte sosem, legfeljebb a már kirakottakból alkotok 1-2 betű hozzárakásával újat, vagy ragozgatom őket. Ez így nekem szenvedés, nem pedig élvezet. El fogom adni, csak lusta vagyok meghirdetni.

Scrabble is a strange game for me. For some reason, Scrabble feels like it is a lot worse than the sum of its parts. I like the mechanical design choice of having a maximum "hand" of seven letters to create a word. I like the bonus point spaces scattered around the game board. And most importantly, Scrabble is a word game. And I love word games. I think that most people generally enjoy word games too, no matter what their gaming background is. They're so accessible for everyone, and just the sheer nature of this genre provides individuals with so many chances and so much agency to excite humor. It's one of the key reasons why popular party games are so often word games.

But for some reason, the positives just don't add up for Scrabble. I want Scrabble to be a game where the players can feel clever and funny at the same time, often creating entertaining words that provides both high points and laughs. Or a game where I can plan ahead of time to make that big word which has others in awe. But in reality, the chances of Scrabble games playing out "optimally" is close to zero. The board states are so often stale and boring. More times than not, your supply of letters are solely composed of vowels. On top of this, the game is always plagued by analysis paralysis. And having AP in Scrabble is not a good time for anyone. The game is extremely reactive, which means that when it isn't your turn, there is really nothing that you are doing except waiting for the other player to make a new word.

And all of what I said above sums up to a game that massively overstays its welcome. I think that if designers continued to develop and actively looked to innovate more on Scrabble, there might have been a smart, satisfying, and smooth word game classic. I know that somewhere out there in my theoretical imagination, there is a version of this game that I love. But alas.

I just despise it with a passion. It's because I always played it with a particular person who is really proficient at it. This changed it from a fun, simple game of making up words to a struggle of trying to fit anything on the board because of that player blocking everyone and making it feel like a slog.

There were no "damn, I can make this amazing move" moments created by making a long word or creatively connecting existing tiles. Every turn was painful and felt like a survival.

I'd rather do literally anything else. Wash the dishes. Do my taxes. Self-flagellate. Anything.

Some letters tend to be slightly overpowered depending on a given language's grammar (e.g. plural of nouns); which could possibly make luck-of-the-draw a valid concern, but honestly I have more prominent issues with Scrabble. Firstly, mechanically speaking, it is a game where you try to find out and lay down the best tile combos to score large amounts of points, which makes the vast majority of your turns about short-term efficiency rather than strategy or voluntary player interaction. (Not my cup of tea.) Secondly, it mostly rewards people with a larger vocabulary; and I don't highly rate gaming as a platform for the validation of social status via a display of the accumulation of vast amounts of arbitrary out-of-game knowledge (what's more, knowledge that's already heavily rewarded by schools and workplaces).

I feel like rating Scrabble low isn't right, but I have a personal problem with it. I've always had some level of analysis paralysis, though I've been working on eliminating that over the years. There are way too many options for my brain to handle. I sit there for WAY too long, trying to figure out how to maneuver my seven letters on the board, while my friends become more and more frustrated. I just can't handle the limitless options, and I end up playing a bunch of dumb three letter words. Yeah, yeah, skill issue on my part, but later word games created limitations that make it more fun to play, without eliminating the strategic knowledge of words.

I'm not good at word games, and my general enjoyment of games in the genre is not high because I feel that I can't compete, at all in them, and have no ability to come up with words. It's not just that I'm bad, my brain lacks the wiring to actually play the game. On occasion, my brain clicks with this one, and I can at least play it though.

I used to rate this a 3, but after having played it quite a few times lately I have to inch this one up to a 4. This is still not the type of game that I'm ever going to request, but as mainstream fare goes it is pretty good, and though there are many games that I enjoy more, I am willing to play this with people who like it. The trick is to play not just for large words, but to the value of the squares on the board. Short words, which are easier to come up with anyway, hence, are actually better in many situations because they are harder for the other player(s) to build off of.

The thing I dislike the most in this game is the ambiguity concerning what a legal word is though, and the fact that strong play seems to revolve around memorizing a bunch of obscure (and questionable) 2 and 3 letter words; but still, for an older title it's not too bad.

My dislike for this game comes not really from the design, which is fine, but the way it plays in practice. People tend to spend a long time on their turns as they mentally line up their letters in all the combinations that fit on the board, leaving me bored when I already know what I'm going to play.
I often end up playing this with people who have memorized all the two-letter word combinations from the official "scrabble dictionary", and it's no use arguing with them. Generally they don't even know what most of these words mean, they just know they're in the dictionary. It's essentially a rules supplement that isn't distributed with the game, and it takes the fun out of it for me.

There's not a great deal to say about Scrabble that hasn't already been written. Our copy was purchased new by our great grandmother and has seen semi-regular family play for generations. Its telling that with no changes of note, the same game has been entertaining families for all this time.

Don't tell my dad. Scrabble is a family tradition; 100 plays surely dramatically underestimates the reality. And I have lots of great memories of playing Scrabble!

But it's a mess. You can fall 150 points behind in the first two turns. You can have unplayable letters all game long. You can draw all the power tiles and run roughshod over your opponent. On top of all that, good play at the intermediate level (when you haven't memorized thousands of letter combinations and aren't able to pull an obscure bingo out of every rack) means blocking out your opponent with cramped, closed-off plays that rely heavily on two-letter words. This makes your own future moves harder, of course, and it's also just sort of ugly. The game's more fun when you aren't trying to win!

Scrabble is a classic word game that combines vocabulary skills with strategic thinking, making it a perfect choice for fans of both casual and competitive gameplay. As the game that got me into board games, it holds a special place in my heart. The challenge of creating high-scoring words while managing your tiles adds depth, and the ever-changing board ensures no two games are alike.

The balance of luck and skill makes each playthrough exciting, and it's a great way to engage with friends and family.

Overall, Scrabble is a timeless game that offers both fun and mental stimulation, making it a staple in any collection.

A classic for a reason! The positional tactics are deeper than many casual players realize, but are completely knowable & optimizable. I keep a timer handy for opponents prone to analysis paralysis, & when their time is up (i like 1 minute!) force them to play their best idea immediately or lose their turn.
My house rules include:
-You may challenge an opponent to demonstrate they know the precise meaning of a word they just played (but i'm not a stickler for perfect phrasing or matching dictionary definitions). If they can't, they have to remove it & lose that turn. If they can, you lose your next turn.
-Acronyms are acceptable if they are in common use PRONOUNCED AS THEY ARE SPELLED (not by saying the letters).
-Proper nouns are acceptable if they are in common use as verbs or common nouns, ie "Jones" meaning a craving or "Lou" meaning a bathroom.
-Common slang is acceptable whether it's in the dictionary or not if it has a standard spelling.

The quintessential word game. Most folks don’t seem to understand this is a tactical game using letters. How to ruin Scrabble while winning super-hard: Play it like an area control game where the goal is to minimize the enemy's playable space while waiting patiently to strike out and capture bonuses. Use the smallest words possible for as long as you can to force the enemy to play the large, scaffolding words that extend your reach into the coveted spots. And even then, do everything you can to constantly curl the game back in on itself to deny them any territory. It's brutal, frustrating, and flies in the face of "vocab-duel"—but that sesquipedalian shit's for suckers.

Update: Oh, man—forget the preceding paragraph and read Stefan Fatsis' Word Freak if you want to get really dirty. First off, memorize ALL THE WORDS, then do shit like play a phony, wait for your opponent to pluralize it, and challenge it off the board. Damn.

Time for an explanation... we all have a childhood treasure trove of tabletop memoirs. Among the spades & spades of All Fours, desperate Market Day sheep sprints, cheating controversies of Cluedo, & Risk's hopeless last stands in Australia. None as I sidle closer to Midlife Corner have weathered quite like this crossword nonsense.

As a dyslexic juvenile with a fructose stunted attention span, I winced knowing Grandma's visits would result in being shackled to a 'game' that felt like homework every evening. Times change, people change. There's a transparent poetry to a zero teach required, pick seven letters & go spell structure. The relatable apex of making dictionary lemonade out of a consonant lemon handful.

A BGG 10 for me doesn't represent perfection, I removed my blindfold to Scrabble's flaws long ago. What it does equate to however, is a legendary status enveloping clarity of a box which has been, & will be, opened again & again, & again... & again, continuing to forge memories hundreds of sittings later. Memories abundant with a sister triple word score crushing her Ma, Pa & brother's morale into the vowelless dirt!

Long live our battered, grubby & beloved Spear's Games copy, my family's last board game bastion.
